case_name: Jethamal Ramkaran v. Seth Haroon and Sons

facts.text: Seth Haroon and Sons was a firm with ten partners.

anchor.surface_text: Seth Haroon and Sons a firm had ten partners.

facts.text: Hindu undivided family of Jethamal Ramkaran mortgaged a house to Seth Haroon and Sons to secure Rs. 40,000.

anchor.surface_text: The Hindu undivided family of Jethamal Ramkaran mortgaged a house belonging to it to Seth Haroon and Sons to secure repayment of Rs. 40,000 due at the foot of an account.

facts.text: Seth Haroon and Sons filed suit No. 12-A of 1936 for recovery of dues by sale of mortgaged house.

anchor.surface_text: Seth Haroon and Sons filed suit No. 12-A of 1936 for recovery of their dues by sale of the mortgaged house.

facts.text: Decree passed in suit on December 28, 1940 by Additional District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: On December 28, 1940, a decree was passed in the suit by the Additional District Judge.

facts.text: Appeal carried to High Court of Nagpur and dismissed subject to slight modification.

anchor.surface_text: The case was carried in appeal to the High Court of Nagpur. But the appeal was dismissed subject to a slight modification to be presently numbericed.

facts.text: Appeal carried to Supreme Court against the decree.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal was carried against the decree to this Court.

facts.text: Nine out of ten members of Seth Haroon and Sons migrated to Pakistan and were declared evacuees during pendency of appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the appeal to this Court, nine out of ten members of Seth Haroon and Sons migrated to Pakistan and were declared evacuees.

facts.text: Supreme Court impleaded Custodian of Evacuee Property as party respondent on March 28, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: By an order passed by this Court on March 28, 1958, the Custodian of Evacuee Property was impleaded as a party respondent in the appeal filed by the mortgagors.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal on August 8, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: This Court dismissed the appeal on August 8, 1958.

facts.text: Mohammad Ayyub, 6th plaintiff and only non-migrated member, applied for decree absolute for sale for himself and as agent of evacuees under general power of attorney.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the 6th plaintiff Mohammad Ayyub-the only member of the firm who had number migrated, for himself and as agent of the evacuees under a general power of attorney applied for a decree absolute for sale.

facts.text: Custodian of Evacuee Property resisted the application by Mohammad Ayyub.

anchor.surface_text: The Custodian of Evacuee Property resisted the application filed by Mohammad Ayyub.

facts.text: Bombay High Court joined Custodian as party to the application but observed rights not decided.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately by the order passed by the High Court of Bombay the Custodian of Evacuee Property was joined as a party to the application. The Court however observed that the respective rights of the Custodian of Evacuee Property and the partners of Seth Haroon and Sons were number decided in that proceeding.

facts.text: Mortgagors contended that nothing due on mortgage, interest wrongly at 4% p.a., costs claim barred by limitation, no interest on costs.

anchor.surface_text: Diverse companytentions were raised by the mortgagors they company- tended, inter alia that on proper account being taken numberhing was due by them on the mortgage, that interest was wrongly calculated at the rate of 4 per annum that the claim for recovery companyts was barred by the law of limitation and that interest companyld number be awarded on companyts.

facts.text: Trial Judge rejected mortgagors' contentions and passed decree for Rs. 34,612-8-1 (principal Rs. 33,866-51 + interest Rs. 746-30).

anchor.surface_text: The learned Trial Judge substantially rejected the companytentions raised by the mortgagors and passed a decree for Rs. 34,612- 8 1 being the aggregate of Rs. 3 3,8 66-51 as principal and Rs. 746-30 as interest.

facts.text: Appeal against trial court order summarily dismissed by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal filed against that order was summarily dismissed by the High Court.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court preferred by mortgagors with special leave.

anchor.surface_text: With special leave, this appeal is preferred by the mortgagors.

facts.text: Mortgagors claimed mortgage satisfied and overpaid due to payments directed to principal.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the mortgagors companytended that on a proper account of the monies paid by them in satisfaction of the dues under the mortgage decree, this mortgage was satisfied and the mortgagees were overpaid.

facts.text: Preliminary decree declared Rs. 42,430-2-6 due upto June 23, 1941 towards principal and interest.

anchor.surface_text: Under the preliminary decree an amount of Rs. 42,430-2-6 was declared due upto June 23, 1941 towards principal and interest.

facts.text: Mortgagors made deposits in court under O. 21 r. 1 CPC, some stated towards principal.

anchor.surface_text: But from time to time they claim to have made deposits in the Court under 0. 21 r. 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure, and in depositing some of the amounts they stated that the payments were towards the principal due.

facts.text: No evidence that mortgagees were informed of or accepted deposits towards principal only.

anchor.surface_text: But there is numberevidence on the record that the mortgagees were informed that the amounts were deposited towards the principal due, number is there evidence that the mortgagees accepted the amounts towards the, principal.

facts.text: Mortgagees credited deposits first to interest and costs, then principal.

anchor.surface_text: The account submitted by the mortgagees shows clearly that they had given credit for the amounts deposited towards the interest and companyts in the first instance and the balance only towards theprincipal.

facts.text: High Court order dated August 10, 1946 specified interest rates: 3% from date of suit to 11-8-1941, 4% from 12-8-1941 to satisfaction.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by order dated August 10, 1946, observed A preliminary decree for sale shall be drawn accordingly and the defendants  the appellants  are given three months time from today to pay off the decretal amount. The amount shall carry interest at L.R. 47 I.A. 150. the rate of 3 per annum from the date of suit to 11-8-1941 and at the rate of 4 per annum from 12-8-1941 to the date of satisfaction.

facts.text: High Court rectification order dated March 31, 1947 specified interest calculation up to November 10, 1946 on Rs. 35,299-1-6.

anchor.surface_text: They then directed that the interest will accordingly be -calculated on Rs. 35,299-1-6 at 3 from October 5, 1936 till August 11, 1941 and at 4 from August 12, 1941 till November 10, 1946. This Comes to Rs. 50,810-4-6. The decree will be amended accordingly.

facts.text: Trial court awarded interest at 3% p.a., High Court in appeal awarded 4%.

anchor.surface_text: It was next urged that the decree was passed by the Trial Court awarding interest at the rate of 3 per annum and the order of the High Court in appeal modifying the original decree by awarding interest at the rate of 4 was erroneous.

facts.text: Bombay High Court order dated November 30, 1964 in First Appeal No. 90 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated November 30, 1964 of the Bombay High Court, Nagpur Bench in First Appeal No. 90 of 1964.

issues.text: Whether the deposits made by mortgagors in court under O.21 r.1 CPC with recitals towards principal were accepted by mortgagees as such, or whether the normal rule of appropriation first to interest and costs applies absent notice and acceptance

anchor.surface_text: deposits in the Court under 0. 21 r. 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure, and in depositing some of the amounts they stated that the payments were towards the principal due. But there is no evidence on the record that the mortgagees were informed that the amounts were deposited towards the principal due, nor is there evidence that the mortgagees accepted the amounts towards the, principal. For quite a long time the mortgagees did not withdraw the amount lying in Court. Unless the mortgagees were informed that the mortgagors had deposited the amount only towards the principal and not towards the interest, and the mortgagees agreed to withdraw the money from the Court accepting the conditional deposit, the normal rule that the amounts deposited in Court should first be applied towards satisfaction of the interest and costs and thereafter towards the principal would apply.

issues.text: Whether the rate of interest after November 10, 1946 was restored to 3% per annum as originally decreed by trial court, or continued at 4% per the High Court directions

anchor.surface_text: Under the decree of the Trial Court interest was awarded at 3. In appeal interest was awarded by the High Court at 4. There after by a modification in an application for correction of thedecree interest at 4 per annum was awarded from August 12, 1941 to November 10, 1946. It was urged, relying upon theorder modifying the rate of interest, that from November 11, 1946 the mortgagees were entitled only to interest at the rate of3.

anchor.surface_text: But there is no evidence on the record that the mortgagees were informed that the amounts were deposited towards the principal due, nor is there evidence that the mortgagees accepted the amounts towards the principal. ... the normal rule that the amounts deposited in Court should first be applied towards satisfaction of the interest and costs and thereafter towards the principal would apply.

arguments.claim: Precedent in Venkatadri Appa Row establishes ordinary rule for unappropriated payments: first to interest

anchor.surface_text: In Venkatadri Appa Row and Others v. Parthasarathi Appa Row the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council observed that upon taking an account of principal and interest due, the ordinary rule with regard to payments by the debtor unappropriated either to principal or interest is that they are first to be applied to the discharge of interest.

holdings.text: Unless the mortgagees were informed that the mortgagors had deposited the amount only towards the principal and not towards the interest, and the mortgagees agreed to withdraw the money from the Court accepting the conditional deposit, the normal rule that the amounts deposited in Court should first be applied towards satisfaction of the interest and costs and thereafter towards the principal would apply.

anchor.surface_text: But there is noevidence on the record that the mortgagees were informed that the amounts were deposited towards the principal due, nor is there evidence that the mortgagees accepted the amounts towards the, principal. For quite a long time the mortgagees did not withdraw the amount lying in Court. Unless the mortgagees were informed that the mortgagors had deposited the amount only towards the principal and not towards the interest, and the mortgagees agreed to withdraw the money from the Court accepting the conditional deposit, the normal rule that the amounts deposited in Court should first be applied towards satisfaction of the interest and costs and thereafter towards the principal would apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of notice to mortgagees of conditional deposits or their acceptance; cites ordinary rule from Privy Council precedent in Venkatadri Appa Row; mortgagees' account credits first to interest/costs.

holdings.text: It was for the mortgagors to plead and prove an agreement that the amounts which were deposited in Court by the mortgagors were accepted by the mortgagees subject to a condition imposed by the mortgagors. In the present case there is no evidence which supports the contention raised by counsel for the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: But the normal rule is that in the case of a debt due with interest any payment made by the debtor is in the first instance to be applied towards satisfaction of interest and thereafter to the principal. It was for the mortgagors to plead and prove an agreement- that the amounts which were deposited in Court by the mortgagors were accepted by the mortgagees subject to a condition imposed by the mortgagors. In the present case there is noevidence which supports the contention raised by counsel for the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Burden on mortgagors to prove acceptance of their appropriation condition; no such evidence on record.

holdings.text: The account submitted by the mortgagees shows clearly that they had given credit for the amounts deposited towards the interest and costs in the first instance and the balance only towards the principal. The account submitted by the mortgagees clearly negatives the plea of the mortgagors.

anchor.surface_text: The account submitted by the mortgagees shows clearly that they had given credit for the amounts deposited towards the interest and costs in the first instance and the balance only towards theprincipal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mortgagees' own account demonstrates application first to interest and costs, contradicting acceptance of principal-only appropriation.

holdings.text: We are unable to hold that the direction is capable of that interpretation. By directing that interest at the rate of 4 from August 12, 1941 to November 10, 1946 shall be calculated on Rs. 35,299-1-6, it was not, and could not be, intended by the High Court that interest after November 10, 1946, was to be awarded only at the rate of 3.

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon this direction, counsel for the appellants contended that the High Court by order dated March 31, 1947, restored for the period after November 10, 1946, the rate of interest as originally awarded by the Court of First Instance. We are unable to hold that the direction is capable of that interpretation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court's rectification order specified calculation only up to Nov 10, 1946 without reducing future rate; no application made for such reduction; consistent with prior directions for 4% to satisfaction.

holdings.text: The section prohibits the Courts from awarding interest exceeding the principal of the loan. ... In the present case the decree awards interest amounting to Rs. 746-30, whereas the principal is Rs. 33,866-51.
holdings.reasoning_summary: S.9 MP Money Lenders Act limits decreed arrears of interest to principal amount; applies to decree (interest Rs.746-30 < principal Rs.33,866-51), not aggregate payments made.

holdings.text: That contention is futile. The Court is concerned at this stage to pass a decree absolute for sale in a mortgage suit. It is not concerned to determine the respective rights of the mortgagees inter se.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Scope of final decree proceedings excludes adjudication of inter se rights among co-mortgagees; mortgagees' interest fully represented.

holdings.text: The learned Trial Judge substantially rejected the contentions raised by the mortgagors and passed a decree for Rs. 34,612-8-1 being the aggregate of Rs. 33,866-51 as principal and Rs. 746-30 as interest.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Trial Judge substantially rejected the contentions raised by the mortgagors and passed a decree for Rs. 34,612- 8 1 being the aggregate of Rs. 3 3,866-51 as principal and Rs. 746-30 as interest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial court rejected claims on limitation for costs and interest on costs; upheld by High Court summary dismissal and this Court by not disturbing.

precedents.citation: Venkatadri Appa Row and Others v. Parthasarathi Appa Row 1 L.R. 47 I.A. 150

anchor.surface_text: In Venkatadri Appa Row and Others v. Parthasarathi Appa Row 1  the Judicial Comnittee of the Privy Council observed that upon taking an account of principal and interest due, the ordinary rule with regard to payments by the debtor unappropriated either to principal or interest is that they are first to be applied to the discharge of interest. Lord Buchmaster delivering the judgment of the Board observed There is a debt due that carries interest. There are moneys that are received without a definite appropriation on the one, side or on the other, and the rule which is well established in ordinary cases is that in those circumstances the money is first applied in payment of interest and then when that is satisfied in payment of the capital. That rule is referred to by Rigby, L. J., in the, case of

precedents.case_name: Venkatadri Appa Row and Others v. Parthasarathi Appa Row
precedents.cited_proposition: upon taking an account of principal and interest due, the ordinary rule with regard to payments by the debtor unappropriated either to principal or interest is that they are first to be applied to the discharge of interest
precedents.cited_holding: There is a debt due that carries interest. There are moneys that are received without a definite appropriation on the one, side or on the other, and the rule which is well established in ordinary cases is that in those circumstances the money is first applied in payment of interest and then when that is satisfied in payment of the capital.

precedents.citation: Parrs Barking Co. v. Yates-1898 2 B. 460

anchor.surface_text: That rule is referred to by Rigby, L. J., in the, case of Parrs Barking Co. v. Yates-1898 2 B. 460 in these words The defendants counsel relied on the old rule that does, no doubt, apply to many cases, namely, that, where both principal and interest are due, the sums paid on account must be applied first to interest. That rule, where it is applicable, is only common justice. To apply the sums paid to principal where interest has accrued upon the debt, and is no paid, would be depriving the creditor of the benefit to which he is entitled under his contract.

precedents.cited_proposition: where both principal and interest are due, the sums paid on account must be applied first to interest. That rule, where it is applicable, is only common justice
precedents.cited_holding: The defendants counsel relied on the old rule that does, no doubt, apply to many cases, namely, that, where both principal and interest are due, the sums paid on account must be applied first to interest. That rule, where it is applicable, is only common justice. To apply the sums paid to principal where interest has accrued upon the debt, and is no paid, would be depriving the creditor of the benefit to which he is entitled under his contract.

anchor.surface_text: But there is noevidence on the record that the mortgagees were informed that the amounts were deposited towards the principal due, nor is there evidence that the mortgagees accepted the amounts towards the, principal. For quite a long time the mortgagees did not withdraw the amount lying in Court. Unless the mortgagees were informed that the mortgagors had deposited the amount only towards the principal and not towards the interest, and the mortgagees agreed to withdraw the money from the Court accepting the conditional deposit, the normal rule that the amounts deposited in Court should first be applied towards satisfaction of the interest and costs and thereafter towards the principal would apply.

But there is noevidence on the record that the mortgagees were informed that the amounts were deposited towards the principal due, nor is there evidence that the mortgagees accepted the amounts towards the, principal. For quite a long time the mortgagees did not withdraw the amount lying in Court. edges.explanation: Holding on burden of proof for agreement addresses the issue of whether deposits were accepted towards principal.

anchor.surface_text: But the normal rule is that in the case of a debt due with interest any payment made by the debtor is in the first instance to be applied towards satisfaction of interest and thereafter to the principal. It was for the mortgagors to plead and prove an agreement- that the amounts which were deposited in Court by the mortgagors were accepted by the mortgagees subject to a condition imposed by the mortgagors. In the present case there is noevidence which supports the contention raised by counsel for the appellant.

But the normal rule is that in the case of a debt due with interest any payment made by the debtor is in the first instance to be applied towards satisfaction of interest and thereafter to the principal. It was for the mortgagors to plead and prove an agreement- that the amounts which were deposited in Court by the mortgagors were accepted by the mortgagees subject to a condition imposed by the mortgagors. In the present case there is noevidence which supports the contention raised by counsel for the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The account submitted by the mortgagees shows clearly that they had given credit for the amounts deposited towards the interest and costs in the first instance and the balance only towards theprincipal.

The account submitted by the mortgagees shows clearly that they had given credit for the amounts deposited towards the interest and costs in the first instance and the balance only towards theprincipal.

Relying upon this direction, counsel for the appellants contended that the High Court by order dated March 31, 1947, restored for the period after November 10, 1946, the rate of interest as originally awarded by the Court of First Instance. We are unable to hold that the direction is capable of that interpretation.

Relying upon this direction, counsel for the appellants contended that the High Court by order dated March 31, 1947, restored for the period after November 10, 1946, the rate of interest as originally awarded by the Court of First Instance. We are unable to hold that the direction is capable of that interpretation.
